720183f-b.title: Manhattan: Greenwich Street - Trinity Place
720183f-b.text:
(1)
The intersection of Greenwich Street, and Srinity Place, at
horris Street, as viewed northward from the Whitehall Building, and
showing S general view of lower Manhattan. On the left is seen
Greenwich Street, (IIinth Ave., Elevated), east side, north from
L.orris, to and including Rector Strcets. On the right apears
Trinity Place, (Sixth Ave., Elevated), east side, north from but not
inlcuding Horris, to, but not including Thames Streets.
June 20, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, from a different angle.
June 20, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

723581f-a.title: Manhattan: Trinity Place - Greenwich Street
723581f-a.text:
(1)
At the intensection of Trinity Place and Greenwich Street. Also
shown is Greenwich Street, east side, north from Trinity Place. The
view shows the divergance of the Sixth and Ninth Aves., Elevated;
the Sixth on Trinity Place and the Ninth on Greenwich Street.
June 20, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, a different angle, and showing the west side of Trinity
Place, through the excavation at the N.E. corner of Trinity Place
at Morris Street.
June 20, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(3) Trinity Place from Morris Street,showing construction after
demolition.
April 28th,I940.
P.L.Sperr,

720176f-a.title: Manhattan: Greenwich Street - Morris Street
720176f-a.text:
Greenwich Street, west side, south from (No. 22-24), a point midway
between Morris Street and Battery Place, to Battery Place. Note overhead
the elevated tracks of the Sixth and Ninth Ave. Lines. At Battery Place
they make a sharp turn eastward to South Ferry.
July 14, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.
720176f-a.folder: Greenwich Street & Morris Street, Manhattan, NY

720172f.title: Manhattan: Greenwich Street - Morris Street
720172f.text:
Greenwich Street(left), south from a point midway between
Morris Street and Battery lace, and to the latter, showing the
lower half of the block scuare site that is to be rased for the
proposed Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel.
Washington Street is on the right, where appears the lower
portions of the Whitehall Building. Attthe top is the Park.
The buildings in the foreground are No's. 22-24 Greenwich Street
and No. 23 Washington Street. They are back to back and adjoin
the parking 1ot shown.
The point of vantage for the photographer is the Cunard
Building on the opposite side of Greenwich Street. The "Eg'
tracks are on same.
Staff Photographer  March, 1940
New York Post
Credit Line Imperative
Wcg Go~
720172f.folder: Greenwich Street & Morris Street, Manhattan, NY

720184f-b.title: Manhattan: Greenwich Street - Trinity Place
720184f-b.text:
The convergence of Greenwich Street (left) and
Trinity Place (right), at Morris Street. Shown at
that point is the triangular structure that separates
the first two mentioned thoroughfares. This building
bears No. 28 Greenwich Street. Note the fact that
the Sixth Avenue Elevated that formerly ran on Trinity
Place has been removed. The Ninth Avenue Line that
still remains on Creenwich Street is to be demolished
sometime in 1940-1.
At the left margin is a portion of the 35 story
No. 19 Rector Street Building. Thru the center is
the Electric Bond & Share Building. On the right,
and separated by Trinity Churchyard are the Trinity
and the Empire Buildings.
April 28, 1940
P. L. Sperr
Greenwich Street and Trinity Place, at point of
intersection.
P. L. Sperr  May 4, 1941
Greenwich St. north of Irinity Pl:ce. Neg. A-145
P.L. Sperr, Motographer  June 26, 1941
